newsitem.title: INDIA: India's BJP says no budget before test vote.
newsitem.headline: India's BJP says no budget before test vote.

text.p: India's opposition Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) said on Tuesday it did not think the government would be able to push the 1997/98 (April-March) budget through parliament before a vote of confidence.
"The budget would not be possible before the confidence vote," BJP spokesman K.R. Malkani told Reuters. "I don't see how Congress or the BJP will agree with that."
Earlier on Tuesday, Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda's United Front coalition said it wanted parliament to approve the investor-friendly budget before the vote of confidence due by April 11.

The minority coalition would need the support of lawmakers from the Congress party or the BJP to ensure passage of the budget. Congress on Sunday withdrew its support for Deve Gowda and staked a claim to form a new government.

While the BJP said it would oppose efforts to approve the budget before the trust vote, the party said it was open to discussing the possibility of having the current parliament approve the budget after the vote.
"The government has to approach us then we can consider the matter," Malkani said. "Let them (the government) convene a meeting. Let them do it properly," BJP president L.K. Advani said.
